title: How to Make a Rainbow Rose

steps.headline: Choose a white rose.
steps.description: Start with a white or very lightly colored rose for making a real rainbow rose. For the purest color, a white rose is best. If you cannot find a white rose to use, try a peach, pale yellow, or light pink rose. Avoid using red roses or dark pink roses; dark colors will not work because the deep shade prevents the color from showing through. Note that the stage the rose is in will affect how fast or slowly the dye takes hold. A rose that is near its blooming stage, or already in its blooming stage, will accept the color more readily. On the other hand, a rose in its bud stage will take much longer.

steps.headline: Trim the stem.
Split the stem into sections.
steps.description:
Use a sharp blade to split the end of the stem into multiple sections. You can use either scissors or a knife, but either way, the tool you choose must be sharp. The stem of a rose is fairly woody, and if you use a dull blade, you could end up causing the stem to break or tear the rose. The cut should extend from the bottom of the rose up to about 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from the base of the petals. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Divide the stem into two to four sections.
steps.description:
If you cut too many sections into the stem, you risk weakening the stem. Note that the number of sections you cut the stem into will determine the number of colors in your rainbow rose. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f5\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f5\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Mix several colors of food coloring into cups of water.
steps.description: Fill a few tall, narrow containers with water and mix in a few drops of food coloring into each container. Choose one different color for each container. As mentioned already, the number of colors should match the number of sections you split the stem into. The more food coloring you use, the brighter the colors will be in the resulting rainbow rose. The best containers will be narrow and sturdy. Avoid using containers with wide lips since the split sections of stem will need to stretch into each container, and wider lips might be harder to stretch the stem sections into. A popsicle mold works well, as do small votive glasses.

steps.headline: Place each stem section into a different container.
steps.description:
Carefully place each split stem section into a different container of colored water, making sure that the cut ends are fully immersed. Exercise extra caution when bending and positioning the stem sections. The split stem is especially weak, and if you move the sections with too much force, you might end up snapping them by accident. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Position the containers of colored water directly next to each other.
steps.description: This will keep the entire structure more secure and limit the amount of space you need to stretch the stems over.

steps.headline: Let the roses sit for a few days.
steps.description:
You should notice some color change within the first 30 minutes, but for a vibrant rainbow rose, you will need to let the rose sit in its dye bath for a few days. It may take a full week before the colors become notably vibrant, but after a single day, each of the petals should be tinted with color. The dyed water will be absorbed through the stem of the rose just like standard water would be taken in. As the dyed water travels throughout the parts of the rose and hydrates the petals, the dye will be deposited in the petals. Since the petals are white, the dye shows through easily. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Select a square of rainbow paper.
Cut the beginning of a circle shape.
steps.description:
Start from the middle of one edge and begin to cut a circle into the square paper, coming as close to the other three edges as possible. Do not yet cut the edges off at this point. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Divert the circle into a spiral.
Cut a tab shape into the center of the spiral.
steps.description:
At the end of the spiral, which should fall out at the exact center, you will naturally end up with a little tab that looks a little wider than the thickness of the spiral. The tab should be fairly circular with a slight notch in it. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/ba\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/ba\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Remove the outside square.
steps.description: Snip off the outside square shape simply by cutting it off at the point where you began your spiral circle shape. The sharp angles and edges of this section will only get in the way of the final rose shape.

steps.headline: Roll up the spiral from the outside in.
Glue the tab to the bottom of the rose.

text:
Using Real Roses Choose a white rose. Start with a white or very lightly colored rose for making a real rainbow rose. For the purest color, a white rose is best. If you cannot find a white rose to use, try a peach, pale yellow, or light pink rose. Avoid using red roses or dark pink roses; dark colors will not work because the deep shade prevents the color from showing through. Note that the stage the rose is in will affect how fast or slowly the dye takes hold. A rose that is near its blooming stage, or already in its blooming stage, will accept the color more readily. On the other hand, a rose in its bud stage will take much longer. Trim the stem. Cut the stem of the rose down so that it is roughly the length you want it to be. Use sharp scissors or a sharp knife to cut the bottom of the stem at an angle. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} To determine the proper length, base the stem height on the height of the containers you will be dyeing the rose in or the height of the vase you plan to store the rose in afterward. The stem of the rose needs to be only a little taller than the length of the final vase. It should not be too much taller than the height of the dyeing containers though, or else the rose will become top-heavy and will not sit well inside the containers. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":293,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":484.3956043956044,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Split the stem into sections. Use a sharp blade to split the end of the stem into multiple sections. You can use either scissors or a knife, but either way, the tool you choose must be sharp. The stem of a rose is fairly woody, and if you use a dull blade, you could end up causing the stem to break or tear the rose. The cut should extend from the bottom of the rose up to about 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from the base of the petals. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Divide the stem into two to four sections. If you cut too many sections into the stem, you risk weakening the stem. Note that the number of sections you cut the stem into will determine the number of colors in your rainbow rose. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Mix several colors of food coloring into cups of water. Fill a few tall, narrow containers with water and mix in a few drops of food coloring into each container. Choose one different color for each container. As mentioned already, the number of colors should match the number of sections you split the stem into. The more food coloring you use, the brighter the colors will be in the resulting rainbow rose. The best containers will be narrow and sturdy. Avoid using containers with wide lips since the split sections of stem will need to stretch into each container, and wider lips might be harder to stretch the stem sections into. A popsicle mold works well, as do small votive glasses. Place each stem section into a different container. Carefully place each split stem section into a different container of colored water, making sure that the cut ends are fully immersed. Exercise extra caution when bending and positioning the stem sections. The split stem is especially weak, and if you move the sections with too much force, you might end up snapping them by accident. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Position the containers of colored water directly next to each other. This will keep the entire structure more secure and limit the amount of space you need to stretch the stems over. Let the roses sit for a few days. You should notice some color change within the first 30 minutes, but for a vibrant rainbow rose, you will need to let the rose sit in its dye bath for a few days. It may take a full week before the colors become notably vibrant, but after a single day, each of the petals should be tinted with color. The dyed water will be absorbed through the stem of the rose just like standard water would be taken in. As the dyed water travels throughout the parts of the rose and hydrates the petals, the dye will be deposited in the petals. Since the petals are white, the dye shows through easily. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Using Paper Select a square of rainbow paper. In order to enjoy the most color from your paper rainbow rose, choose a square of paper with a rainbow print on the front and back. You could also choose a square sheet of paper with a white side, plain color side, or a pattern on the opposite side. Play around with different types of paper to find the look you like best. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Origami paper works especially well. The standard size for origami paper is 9 by 9 inches (23 by 23cm). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} If starting with plain white paper, you can use crayons or colored pencils to color a rainbow pattern over the entire sheet of paper. For best results, try layering the colors diagonally across the square from one corner to the opposite corner. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut the beginning of a circle shape. Start from the middle of one edge and begin to cut a circle into the square paper, coming as close to the other three edges as possible. Do not yet cut the edges off at this point. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Divert the circle into a spiral. Once you get close to the starting point of your circle, shift the cutting line in by about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm). Continue cutting around the inner perimeter of your spiral until you reach the center. The thickness of the spiral should be similar all the way around, meaning that the approximate thickness of the spiral should be about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) evenly. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut the spiral free-hand. You do not need to be precise with this technique. In fact, this rose looks best when you maintain a principle of “wabi-sabi,” a Japanese aesthetic focused on the beauty of the imperfect. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut a tab shape into the center of the spiral. At the end of the spiral, which should fall out at the exact center, you will naturally end up with a little tab that looks a little wider than the thickness of the spiral. The tab should be fairly circular with a slight notch in it. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove the outside square. Snip off the outside square shape simply by cutting it off at the point where you began your spiral circle shape. The sharp angles and edges of this section will only get in the way of the final rose shape. Roll up the spiral from the outside in. Roll the entire spiral up toward its center, rolling along the top-side of the paper. As you start, the roll should be as tight as possible. Use both hands to roll up the paper spiral. Hold the developing roll in between two fingers on one hand and use your other hand to maneuver the remaining paper around the roll to incorporate it. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Initially, the final roll will look very tight and not very rose-like. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/42/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/42/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Adjust the tightness of the spiral. Slowly release the tension holding the spiral together, allowing the roll to loosen and unravel slightly while still maintaining its basic form. Let the tension drop less for a tighter roll and let it drop more for a looser rose. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Glue the tab to the bottom of the rose. Add a drop of hot glue onto the top-side of the tab and firmly press it against the bottom of the rose. Make sure that each spiral is caught on the glue. Make sure to use hot glue or a glue that dries almost instantly. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} You also need to make sure that the edge of each spiral sticks to the glue. Otherwise, the rose may unravel once you release it. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} As soon as the glue dries, set the rose down. Your paper rainbow rose should be complete. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Repeat to make more!
sentences: Using Real Roses Choose a white rose.
Start with a white or very lightly colored rose for making a real rainbow rose.
For the purest color, a white rose is best.
If you cannot find a white rose to use, try a peach, pale yellow, or light pink rose.
Avoid using red roses or dark pink roses; dark colors will not work because the deep shade prevents the color from showing through.
Note that the stage the rose is in will affect how fast or slowly the dye takes hold.
A rose that is near its blooming stage, or already in its blooming stage, will accept the color more readily.
On the other hand, a rose in its bud stage will take much longer.
Trim the stem.
Cut the stem of the rose down so that it is roughly the length you want it to be.
Use sharp scissors or a sharp knife to cut the bottom of the stem at an angle.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fb\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fb\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} To determine the proper length, base the stem height on the height of the containers you will be dyeing the rose in or the height of the vase you plan to store the rose in afterward.
The stem of the rose needs to be only a little taller than the length of the final vase.
It should not be too much taller than the height of the dyeing containers though, or else the rose will become top-heavy and will not sit well inside the containers.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3c\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3c\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":293,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":484.3956043956044,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Split the stem into sections.
Use a sharp blade to split the end of the stem into multiple sections.
You can use either scissors or a knife, but either way, the tool you choose must be sharp.
The stem of a rose is fairly woody, and if you use a dull blade, you could end up causing the stem to break or tear the rose.
The cut should extend from the bottom of the rose up to about 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from the base of the petals.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Divide the stem into two to four sections.
If you cut too many sections into the stem, you risk weakening the stem.
Note that the number of sections you cut the stem into will determine the number of colors in your rainbow rose.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f5\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/f5\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-3Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Mix several colors of food coloring into cups of water.
Fill a few tall, narrow containers with water and mix in a few drops of food coloring into each container.
Choose one different color for each container.
As mentioned already, the number of colors should match the number of sections you split the stem into.
The more food coloring you use, the brighter the colors will be in the resulting rainbow rose.
The best containers will be narrow and sturdy.
Avoid using containers with wide lips since the split sections of stem will need to stretch into each container, and wider lips might be harder to stretch the stem sections into.
A popsicle mold works well, as do small votive glasses.
Place each stem section into a different container.
Carefully place each split stem section into a different container of colored water, making sure that the cut ends are fully immersed.
Exercise extra caution when bending and positioning the stem sections.
The split stem is especially weak, and if you move the sections with too much force, you might end up snapping them by accident.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Position the containers of colored water directly next to each other.
This will keep the entire structure more secure and limit the amount of space you need to stretch the stems over.
Let the roses sit for a few days.
You should notice some color change within the first 30 minutes, but for a vibrant rainbow rose, you will need to let the rose sit in its dye bath for a few days.
It may take a full week before the colors become notably vibrant, but after a single day, each of the petals should be tinted with color.
The dyed water will be absorbed through the stem of the rose just like standard water would be taken in.
As the dyed water travels throughout the parts of the rose and hydrates the petals, the dye will be deposited in the petals.
Since the petals are white, the dye shows through easily.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a7\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-6Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Using Paper Select a square of rainbow paper.
In order to enjoy the most color from your paper rainbow rose, choose a square of paper with a rainbow print on the front and back.
You could also choose a square sheet of paper with a white side, plain color side, or a pattern on the opposite side.
Play around with different types of paper to find the look you like best.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9a\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9a\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Origami paper works especially well.
The standard size for origami paper is 9 by 9 inches (23 by 23cm).

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9b\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9b\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If starting with plain white paper, you can use crayons or colored pencils to color a rainbow pattern over the entire sheet of paper.
For best results, try layering the colors diagonally across the square from one corner to the opposite corner.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1a\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1a\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-7Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut the beginning of a circle shape.
Start from the middle of one edge and begin to cut a circle into the square paper, coming as close to the other three edges as possible.
Do not yet cut the edges off at this point.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Divert the circle into a spiral.
Once you get close to the starting point of your circle, shift the cutting line in by about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm).
Continue cutting around the inner perimeter of your spiral until you reach the center.
The thickness of the spiral should be similar all the way around, meaning that the approximate thickness of the spiral should be about 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) evenly.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut the spiral free-hand.
You do not need to be precise with this technique.
In fact, this rose looks best when you maintain a principle of “wabi-sabi,” a Japanese aesthetic focused on the beauty of the imperfect.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1a\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1a\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut a tab shape into the center of the spiral.
At the end of the spiral, which should fall out at the exact center, you will naturally end up with a little tab that looks a little wider than the thickness of the spiral.
The tab should be fairly circular with a slight notch in it.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/ba\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/ba\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-10Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Remove the outside square.
Snip off the outside square shape simply by cutting it off at the point where you began your spiral circle shape.
The sharp angles and edges of this section will only get in the way of the final rose shape.
Roll up the spiral from the outside in.
Roll the entire spiral up toward its center, rolling along the top-side of the paper.
As you start, the roll should be as tight as possible.
Use both hands to roll up the paper spiral.
Hold the developing roll in between two fingers on one hand and use your other hand to maneuver the remaining paper around the roll to incorporate it.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c4\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c4\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Initially, the final roll will look very tight and not very rose-like.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/42\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/42\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Adjust the tightness of the spiral.
Slowly release the tension holding the spiral together, allowing the roll to loosen and unravel slightly while still maintaining its basic form.
Let the tension drop less for a tighter roll and let it drop more for a looser rose.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9e\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/9e\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-12Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Glue the tab to the bottom of the rose.
Add a drop of hot glue onto the top-side of the tab and firmly press it against the bottom of the rose.
Make sure that each spiral is caught on the glue.
Make sure to use hot glue or a glue that dries almost instantly.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/89\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} You also need to make sure that the edge of each spiral sticks to the glue.
Otherwise, the rose may unravel once you release it.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0f\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0f\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} As soon as the glue dries, set the rose down.
Your paper rainbow rose should be complete.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cb\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cb\/Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Rainbow-Rose-Step-13Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Repeat to make more!
tyn_section: Vases, popsicle mold, or similar containers
Hot glue gun or fast-drying glue
